comments.author: Michael Lydeamore
comments.text: Is there a reference for this?

replies.author: Alex
replies.text:
@cockburn2008: 
This discontinuity can cause cognitive and mechanical burdens for users, who must mentally assimilate
the overall structure of the information space and their location within it, as well as
manipulate controls in order to navigate through it. For example, Grudin [2001] reports
that reducing the discontinuity between views “reduces the cognitive load by allowing
rapid glances to check on information; for example between a bird’s-eye view of an
entire graphical object and a close-up of a detail.”

comments.author: Michael Lydeamore
comments.text: This isn't really 'in contrast to' - these packages do that also. Possibly can be dropped, or reworded into another sentence.

comments.author: Michael Lydeamore
comments.text: How was this done? What sort of method is it?

replies.author: Alex
replies.text:
DOI(x | y) = API(x) − D(x, y)
x = a data element
y = the current focus
API(x) = a-priori interest (pre-assigned importance)
D(x, y) = spatial or semantic distance between x and y
Items whose DOI falls below a threshold are suppressed or shown with reduced detail. This allows the interface to maintain global context while emphasizing relevant regions, and was the conceptual basis for fisheye views.
